key_points: Colin Powell's death is seen as the loss of a national icon and hero, celebrated for breaking down barriers in his roles as a soldier and diplomat.
Col. Maurice Barnett, the Deputy Commanding Officer of the United States Army Cadet Command, reflects on Powell's significant influence on his career and on soldiers worldwide.
Barnett sees Powell's achievements as a reflection of what is possible for individuals with similar backgrounds and modest beginnings.
Powell's presence was notable in various media, including a 1989 edition of the Fort Knox Newspaper, 'Inside the Turret', highlighting his visit and talk to graduating cadets.
Powell is remembered for having a lasting impact on Fort Knox and Army Cadets, embodying qualities that current ROTC students can identify with.
His career includes becoming the youngest and first officer to be the joint chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff in 1989.
In 2001, Powell became the first Black secretary of state, marking another historic milestone.
Powell was inducted into the ROTC Hall of Fame in 2016 as part of its inaugural class, recognizing his contributions and leadership.
Barnett shared a personal connection with Powell, seeing him as an inspirational figure who demonstrated the potential to rise to high levels in the military.
The legacy of Colin Powell continues to inspire and influence young soldiers and cadets across the United States.
spokespersons: Col. Maurice Barnett (Deputy Commanding Officer, United States Army Cadet Command)
